newsitem.title: CHINA: China finance chief says nation must tighten belt.
newsitem.headline: China finance chief says nation must tighten belt.

text.p: China's Minister of Finance Liu Zhongli said on Monday the state would have to tighten its belt for a long time to curb rapidly rising expenditure.
Growth in state revenue had averaged more than 90 billion yuan ($10.8 billion) a year from 1993 to 1996, but that was not enough to cover rising expenditure, state radio quoted Liu as saying.
"We must tighten our belts, and moreover, we must tighten our belts for a very long time," Liu said.
In 1997, Beijing should set up an apparatus for budgetary control and rein in the rapid growth of spending, Liu said.
China should "bring the fine traditions of practising economy and opposing waste into financial management," Liu said.
Liu did not elaborate on what this would entail but said China should ensure fiscal support for agriculture, education, science and technology and government organs.
Earlier this month Liu said China had reported a basically balanced budget for 1996, with the state deficit held within the targeted range.
State revenue increased by 18.1 percent in the first 11 months, official reports have said.
The finance ministry has forecast a budget deficit of 60 billion yuan in 1997, with financial revenue seen increasing by 13-15 percent.
